Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Smart Window Film for Ultra-high Thermal and Acoustic Insulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will not only produce a multifunctional thermal insulation structure that is easy to install onto any existing single-, double-, or even triple-pane windows in reducing total building energy consumption, but also improve water condensation issues and occupant discomfort that are associated with single-pane windows in cool climates. Furthermore, the smart window system includes a soundproof layer that can attenuate noise, outperforming a triple-pane window without deterioration of optical properties. In cold climates, the film, which uses a low-e coating, will prove the exterior temperature condition (< -5 Â°C) required for interior condensation to occur in winter. The proposed approach outperforms existing doubleor triple-pane windows with Al frames and conventional spacers and will enjoy a share of the already-popular energy saving windows market (61.6%, or ~$10 billion Global). According to our cost estimate for a 1 square foot smart window of the design dimension proposed (including all chemical and energy costs in a scalable roll-to-roll process), a $5/ft2 manufacturing cost can be achieved, providing a great incentive with a pay-off period within 5 years for customers.

The proposed project will address thermal, optical, and acoustic concerns on an existing singlepane window simultaneously. The thin window film realizes a low U-factor (≤ 0.45) within 3mm in thickness, through the combination of a super-low thermal conductive supporting material, and two distinct coatings (low transmittance in infrared region) on a thin film, which can be readily attached to a single-pane glass window. It also yields noise attenuation ≥ 50 dB with designed cavities embedded in the window film to attenuate noise transmission. The resulting sheet can not only enhance acoustic insulation performance but also reduce the volume of the porous membrane used and thus cost. In addition, the smart film demonstrates all-season operation of smart-glass based on temperature-responsive, tunable Near-IR transmittance in a tunable thermochromic coating without electric power consumption. The film controls haze by Page 11 controlling light scattering in the interface of granulate materials and reduces the volume fraction of the structural material used in the proposed smart film. The combined low-e and thermochromic coatings will help the film achieve a high color rendering index because visible transmittances for the coatings are excellent complements to each other, thus exhibiting a broad and uniform transmission over the visible spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this award is to prototype a smart window with cost-effective technologies to improve the thermal insulation (U-factor), reduce cold weather condensation of single-pane windows, and provide outstanding acoustic attenuation, capable of being applied onto existing windowpanes.

During Phase I efforts, we have encountered challenges in four aspects: (1) acoustic insulation performance, (2) low-e coating and thermochromic material synthesis, (3) optical clarity of the product, and (4) prototyping with appropriate materials. The simulation results conducted in this past phase serve as the solid guidance of our upcoming Phase II manufacturing and commercialization work.

The overall outcomes during Phase I execution period include having conducted numerical modeling for (1) acoustic insulation and for (2) thermal insulation, accomplished (3) the synthesis of thermochromic materials for coating in various metal doping ratios, (4) the prototyping of small samples (~1.5” in diameter) and the minimal viable product (1 ft x 1 ft), demonstrated in Figure 1, and (5) filed one provisional application in September, 2017.

Acoustics: The acoustic metamaterial design has been explored in various versions with the smallest functional size. Several optimized configurations have been investigated and achieved satisfied results through the geometric parameter studies. However, the most challenging part in this product development is to fulfill the customers’ need in clarity (or aesthetics). With the support from NSF, this simulation work can then be accomplished, providing valuable guidance for the upcoming large-sale simulations and the follow-on optimization before production.

Optics – Our team adopted various hydrothermal synthesis methods to prepare thermochromic nanostructuress. In the experiment, metal dopant contents varying from 1.0 at% to 2.0 at% were applied. Then the phase change temperature Tc was measured to determine the relationship between the W doping content and the corresponding Tc. As shown in Figure 2, Tc of the candidate material decreases with the increase of the metal-doping content. The increase in the metal content from 0 at% to 2 at% significantly reduces Tc from 68.5 °C to 12.1 °C, which is much lower than room temperature, successfully proving the feasibility of this method. Meanwhile, this method shows a great potential for a mass production due to its high yield, low cost, and simple preparation process, having a bright future for commercialization. The work in Phase I have paved a way to tune the IR reflection and absorption properties of the smart windows.

Low-e Silver Coating: The coating has successfully been demonstrated onto PMMA substrates (1” in diameter) at a series of thickness, ranging from 0 nm to 8 nm in thickness (Figure 3). It is hardly differentiable for the coated samples when the silver thickness is greater than 2 nm. It is anticipated that emissivity ratings will highly depend on the thickness of the coated silver.

Thermal: Three different types of candidate materials: Sylgard 182 (cured PDMS), aerogel, and air/aerogel have been simulated and evaluated during Phase I. The team obtained the corresponding U-values when the room side emissivity is 0.1. The results demonstrated that all the U values are lower than 0.45 BTU/ft2/hr/°F, which imply that for applications with thin materials, such as the window film we are currently developing, conduction heat transfer plays a minor role. Instead, radiative low-emissivity coating plays a much more dominating role by reflecting thermal energy of interest back to the interior environment. The overall U-factor can therefore be significantly reduced.
